comments.commentBody: Particularly direct, refreshing by you all, too, here today. Sobriety and frankness are vital. Veering into even slight vengeance-writing now won't help. There's enough material for NYT's to relish blunt.

About as reassuring and competent a SecDef pick as anyone could hope for. The Times should have offered a full-throated endorsement, not this tenuous and nitpicking approval.

Sad!

What "experience"? Great military experience, no civilian management experience, no policy formulation experience. & I guess another qualification is that he isn't insane.

The fawning among journalists--Tom Friedman, Mark Shields--is the most disgusting I've ever seen. Just yesterday Trump rewarded Pakistan & suggested he would take their side against India; told Duterte that he's doing a great job with his anti-drug campaign (which has so far resulted in death-squad murders of 4000 people); and provoked China by talking to the pro-independence president of Taiwan (which we & everyone else regard as part of China).

The fact that Mattis was not above personally serving cookies on Christmas Eve does not make him a compelling leader, except perhaps to his troops. He doesn't have troops anymore. He doesn't even have us. He has Trump. & Bannon & Flynn & Sessions & Popeo ... & for State, Giuliani? If it's Romney, he's gonna be neutered. & in either case, will Mad Dog Mattis.

You failed to mention General Dynamics.He is on the board and has received over a million dollars since retiring.As Elizabeth Warren has said,the defense contractors are dancing in the streets in DC.The new dynamic duo may have no problem lighting up half the Eastern Hemisphere....
One does not reason with a "mad dog".  How his foreign acts will pan out remains to be seen, but there is a risk to demonizing a religion saying you don't.
I don't trust anyone who's wulling to work for Trump.

"America’s military has always grown stronger when barriers to inclusion have been dismantled."

I'm not sure why it continues to surprise me to see such incredibly bankrupt reasoning on the NYT editorial page. But this is just, like, whoa.

Always stronger via inclusion, you say? Then by all means, let's strip off all the ageist and ableist barriers, and allow 90-year-olds and wheelchair-bound paralytics into front-line combat roles.

This bogus, sloganeering method of "argument" does nobody any good. Somebody on the editorial board PLEASE read a freshman-level book on principles of reasoning, as soon as possible.
Isn't our military supposed to be under civilian control?

Are you folks on the Board naive or simply whistling past the graveyard? Trump is notoriously thin-skinned when challenged and, at his age, incapable of learning anything new. Do you seriously imagine he would hire anyone who disagrees with him or who would not toe the company line to the letter? The second Mattis said or did anything not entirely consistent with Trump's pronouncements he'd either be out on his ear or so badly undercut that he would become a cipher. The same, naturally, holds true for any of Trump's Cabinet.

You are looking for light where there won't be any.
So a guy with the nickname, Mad Dog, is the voice of reason:)

Man the bar is low for Trump appointments but 'yes' he certainly seems to reject the incredibly petulant and foolish ideas of dismantling NATO, giving Japan the Bomb or getting rid of the deal with Iran. And, I guess, beggars can't be choosers.
Latest news from the Capitol is Dems want to block his nomination.

No one can question General Mattis' incredible service to our country. But, since he's obviously intelligent, I'm having trouble with his concern about women in combat. He must know about the compulsory military service in Israel's IDF for everyone, men and women. I believe many female IDF members have served in combat. And, would any of you want to mess with any of them? I seriously doubt it, unless you were a fully-trained, combat-ready individual. Otherwise, you would get your butt kicked. No weapons needed.

What about his ties to Theranos, the disgraced (OK, fraudulent) diagnostics company? He SERVES ON THE BOARD. Suggests he either got conned or is part of the con, not good either way.

I cannot fathom why so many people got taken in by Theranos, seems to embody the very anti-science post-truth thinking that got us Trumped, packaged in a thin Silicon valley shell. If something sounds too good to be true, it probably is. Not exactly reassuring evidence of good judgment for a Secretary of Defense.

So, does retired General Mattis have any relevant experience in managing complicated technology deployment and acquisition for the military, showing his talent  and character while interacting with political and industry leaders of all types?  Yes, and in a big way. He's now on the board of Theranos. As Centcom commander he tried to get their scam gadget battlefield tested using his troops as guinea pigs - then tried to overrule the objections  raised by the Army medical testing group while being influenced by a college dropout CEO, her lobbyists and his geriatric power broker friends who were all hoping to get rich from it.

With a fool at the top, this is certainly a good sign.  When H.L. Mencken said the boobs would eventually chose one of their own to reside in the White House, he could not have imagined a more perfect fit than The Donald.  Now, if he selects Romney for Secretary of State, world leaders will have at least to responsible high officials to run interference for them, and we may be safe.

His willingness to criticize openly his Commander-in-Chief about Guantanamo Bay and his resistance to the President's policy on openly gay and transgender troops are too disturbing than to be ignored by the Editorial Board. Such behavior by any military officer -- especially a senior one -- violates the tradition of civilian control of the military and should be disqualifying permanently, especially as Secretary of Defense, and not just for seven years.

Notwithstanding the gratitude and respect General Mattis has earned by his service, words and phrases like "Bonapartism" and "American Caesar" come too easily to mind. I have no faith that Trump or General Mattis will address these concerns, but I had hoped that the Times Editorial Board would have discussed them with a little more depth than their cavalier ignorance of them in this editorial.

The one guy who will stand up against Trump should not be summarily dismissed by Democrats. On this issue, the Dartmouth-grad senator from New York should not engage in the obstruction tactics used by Republicans the past eight years. With Jeffrey Beauregard Sessions, by all means obstruct his appointment.

Has anyone read the NY Times Picks comments for this article ?

They read like a Democratic "think speak" group, each and every comment is opposed to President Elect Trump. Each outlining the best approach a Democrat would have taken without consideration of Republican perspectives.

The problem is that a Democrat was not elected, President Obama has run the country his way for eight years, the American people have elected Donald Trump to do the same.

It is time to unite behind our new leader and to stop opposing his administration before it even starts. Remember folks the NY Times speaks just for itself and it's radicialized readers, so smarten up.

Trump seems to have connected the title of cabinet posts with his perceived notion of positions he holds in regards to them, not the fact the posts are responsible for making the machinery of the government work, and work as efficiently and effectively as possible. We see it with DeVos, Price, and essentially everyone else who has been tapped. Big on their stands and opinions, short on the skills to manage, direct and make successful the agencies they will head. General Mattis does not seem to fall neatly into that category, but his admirable service record, his leadership of troops, and his intellectual curiosity are not the essential skills needed to run DOD.

Maybe he will demonstrate he has them without having used them. Maybe he will refrain from trying to run the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Maybe he will be the voice of reason in the re-purposed swamp that Trump promised to drain (but just one of many things we sure won't happen). But should that be enough to give him a pass? My guess is that he's a man of integrity and firm beliefs, and he would walk away without regret or a backward glance if things start to go terribly wrong, not of his doing but because of the administration about to take over. Then where would we be?

So I come down on the side of confirm him, hope for the best, send your sons and daughters to Canada if a draft reappears, and pray we stay out of war zones. Fat chance.
Only if you think the wars this century have been a success would you appoint a general to head the Pentagon - the very heart of the DC swamp

I am shocked, and I deplore the Time's endorsement of Mattis. The history of nations who bring generals into a democratic administration have a history of going bad. Generals by nature of authoritarian in their outlook and tend toward ridged control. And, as to the waiver that will be needed, what is the sense of having the law in the first place if it is to be waived on political grounds. We will alll agree the Marshall was a great exemption, and his tenure was outstanding.

Maybe.

.....but the number of Generals on Trumps' cabinet feels alarming to me.

.....and the continuing train wreck that is Trump feels alarming to me too.

This editorial is a bit like saying "The patient has tumors in his lungs, stomach and liver but at least it hasn't spread to his limbs"......

We can only hope that if James Mattis is confirmed that he is able to withstand the bullying tactics of Donald Trump and educate him on our roll in the free world.

Donald Trump's view of the world is strictly as a profit making scheme and not one of a diplomat and leader of the free world. Trump's perspective is more akin to a someone leaving grammar school singing the song "Columbus sailed the ocean blue in 1492........" and not one of the complex interactions and role we as a nation plays in the world.

Hopefully James Mattis and whoever the Secretary of State is providing it is not the mentioned possibilities of Giuliani or Bolton, but one of real substance with a modern realistic world perspective of the role we play, will be able to guide Trump in the right direction.

The comment that Gen. Mattis holds different opinions than Trump presumes Trump holds any opinions beyond his perceived need to say whatever it takes to win over the audience at the moment. That aside, please let's now get a responsible Secretary of State, so that our foreign policy interests can be safeguarded until this clown in voted of out office.
